comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
Maryborough was still used in 1959?
Oh, I see it's from the Irish Times. Maybe they had their own style manual which kept the old names. Interesting.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Interesting to see the little PWD inspection car of the day, possibly of GSWR/GSR origin. The derailed Sulzer loco No.B101 is just visible on the left.

comment.author: 75116182@N04
comment._content: Really nice photo!  Let's do some work! All in line to work together!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
39191857@N05
comment._content: Maryborough indeed, my father who worked for CIE and did many runs on that line always called it that.  He retired in 1959 and it may have been in common usage until about then.  This is a great example of how things have changed in a relatively short space of time.  A complete absence of PPE for the men, not even gloves. I think that virtually every man on the rail has a cap on with the exception of the man with the hat.  There is an almost complete lack of automation there so it is going to be hard manual labour all the way.  Weedkiller is noxious stuff now and was no different then but the drums are just pushed to one side and no notice is being taken of them.  Very sad about the Inspector RIP.

comment.author: 35005310@N02
comment._content:
Not a High Viz jacket or clipboard in sight, and no one is wearing overalls or work gloves either!  
A fabulous picture!  I cane just imagine the response fro a gang of workers these days if they were asked to move a rail in this manner!

comment.author: 31536722@N00
comment._content: Now that's what you call manual labour! A great shot.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It was originally Portlaoise. Co.Laois was originally named Queens County after Queen Mary, with Portlaoise named Maryborough.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] PWD stands for Permanent Way Department, usually anything to do with maintaining the railway's infrastructure, the PWD term is still used a lot on Irish Rail and elsewhere.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Maryborough was the old name for Portlaoise maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,646956,698327,7,9 PWD = Permanent Way Department Railways were built using a ramshackle temporary way. When the trackbed was stabilised the Permanent Way was laid on top. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Track_%28rail_transport%29

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] D'oh! Mortified that I didn't know Maryborough = Portlaoise. And thanks for PWD explanation.

comment._content: Michael Harrington of Inchicore was my grandad. I'd love to know more about this incident as we only have a very old newspaper clipping about it

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Hello there [http://www.flickr.com/photos/100074971@N08]! I'm afraid we don't have any more information than is contained in the comments here, and in the report from the Irish Times. You might try the Irish Railway Records Society or the Railway Preservation Society of Ireland? I can't see from your profile where you're based, but if you're anywhere near us, you could call in and search in our newspapers for yourself...

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/100074971@N08] This is bit long for a Flickr comment(!) but it's from the pen of J.P O'Dea himself, from his Kildare to Portlaoise memoir published in IRRS Journal 124. At MP 34 the gradient eases but falls sharply again by Hybla bridge at MP 34 1/4. This is where the 03.50 down Waterford goods was derailed on Good Friday 27 March 1959. Most CIE passenger trains were cancelled on that day (as was the practice at that period) and the local ganger decided to change some rails on the down road. Shortly after the work was due to commence, the look-out man was sent off to his post of duty to place detonators but before he could reach it, the ganger, sure that the goods must have long passed by, removed a length of rail. What he did not know was that on that particular morning the goods had been severely delayed in Kildare, and was trying to make up time on the falling gradient towards Monasterevan. To the horror of the gang they saw the goods bearing down on them. The driver, Driver Mickey Harrington, braked hard but was unable to stop the loose-coupled train. The locomotive concerned was B101, a Birmingham Railway Carriage & Wagon Co. Sulzer locomotive of the A1A-A1A type, travelling at 45 mph, and some of the leading wagons of the train were derailed blocking both up and down lines. The leading wagons, containing sodium chlorate, went on fire and were either destroyed or badly damaged, although no-one was injured. While the line was closed train services were diverted via Carlow and Kilkenny to Abbeyleix and Portlaoise. The up line was reopened in the early hours of Saturday morning and the down line at 17.00 that same day. Three steam cranes from; Inchicore, Broadstone and Athlone, were used for clearing the debris from the track. Tragically, the Permanent Way Inspector at Portlaoise on hearing of the derailment suffered a heart attack and died.
